name: textile production, cotton, weaving | textile, woven cotton | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/21220/documentation

Inventory refers to 1 kg woven textile in Bangladesh in 2017. This dataset covers warp beaming, sizing, knotting & drawing, weaving and inspection of the woven textile.;Weaving is a textile production method which involves interlacing a set of longer threads (called the warp) with a set of crossing threads (called the weft). This is done on a frame or machine known as a loom, a device that holds the warp threads in place while filling threads are woven through them. The way the warp and filling threads interlace with each other is called the weave. The machine runs on electricity and lubricants. Moreover, maize starch is required as sizing agent. Hence, main inputs of the weaving process are cotton yarn, maize starch, water, electricity, and lubricants. ;Data were collected from the representative mills in Bangladesh. The mills were chosen to provide data based on their technical representation of the current state of business and their willingness to participate.

The activity starts with the warp beaming of the greige yarn.

The activity ends with the inspection of the woven fabric.
category: C:Manufacturing/13:Manufacture of textiles/131:Spinning, weaving and finishing of textiles/1312:Weaving of textiles

exchanges.description: Literature value. Collected data underestimated greatly the electricity consumption as it neglected the use of diesel powered generator during the load-shedding period. The electricity consumption agreggates electricity from the grid and form the generator, as no data on the shares of those supplies was found for the textile industry. The average value is taken from the Velden et al 2014 for 1/tex 0.05.
